title: What Country Is Elon Musk From? Born in South Africa (2025)
answer:
## The Direct Answer: I Am From South Africa

I was born in Pretoria, South Africa on June 28, 1971. That is the country I am from. South Africa is where I took my first steps, read my first books, wrote my first lines of code, and formed the foundational experiences that would shape everything I would later build.

Pretoria is not just any South African city. It is the administrative capital, situated in the northeastern part of the country in what is now called Gauteng province. The city sits on the South African Highveld at an elevation of roughly 1,350 meters above sea level. When I was growing up there, Pretoria was known for its jacaranda trees, which paint the streets purple every October and November. It was a city of government buildings, embassies, and a certain conservative formality that characterized much of white South African society during the apartheid era.

My South African identity runs deeper than just a birthplace. I am ethnically a mix of British and Dutch ancestry on my father's side, and Canadian on my mother's side. My mother, Maye Musk, was born in Saskatchewan, Canada, but her family immigrated to South Africa when she was just two years old. So even my Canadian heritage has South African roots in terms of where it was cultivated and expressed during my formative years.

I spent seventeen years in South Africa before leaving for Canada in 1989. Those years encompassed my entire childhood and adolescence. Every formative experience, from learning to read obsessively to getting my first computer to being beaten unconscious by school bullies, happened on South African soil.

## My South African Childhood: The Early Years

Being from South Africa in the 1970s and 1980s was a particular experience that is hard to convey to people who did not live through it. The country was internationally isolated due to apartheid sanctions. We could not get many products, films, or cultural materials that were freely available elsewhere. This isolation had contradictory effects. On one hand, it limited exposure to the wider world. On the other hand, it created a kind of intellectual hunger in those of us who wanted more.

I was an intensely curious child, bordering on obsessive. I would read for ten hours a day when given the opportunity. The local library in Pretoria became my refuge. I systematically worked through their collection, including the Encyclopaedia Britannica, which I read cover to cover by age nine. When you cannot easily access new information from the outside world, you consume everything available to you.

My parents divorced when I was around eight or nine years old. After the divorce, I initially lived with my mother but later chose to live with my father. This decision was complicated, as my relationship with my father was and remains difficult. But at the time, I felt drawn to stay. Perhaps I felt my father needed company, or perhaps I was simply making the choice a child makes without fully understanding its implications.

School in South Africa was brutal for me. I was small, bookish, and socially awkward. This combination made me a target. The bullying I experienced was not the mild teasing that the word sometimes implies in contemporary discourse. It was systematic physical violence. Groups of boys would hunt me. On one occasion, they threw me down a concrete staircase and beat me until I lost consciousness. I was hospitalized. My face was so swollen that my father did not recognize me when he came to the hospital.

These experiences in South Africa taught me something important: the world is not inherently fair or kind. Systems do not protect you simply because you are innocent. You have to develop your own resilience. You have to be willing to take punishment and keep moving forward. This lesson, learned through pain on South African playgrounds and school corridors, has served me throughout my business career.

## The South African Context: Apartheid and Its Shadow

Being from South Africa means being from a country that was, during my childhood, defined by apartheid. This system of institutionalized racial segregation and discrimination was the organizing principle of South African society. As a white South African, I benefited from this system whether I chose to or not. The schools I attended, the neighborhoods I lived in, the opportunities available to my family, all were shaped by apartheid's architecture of racial privilege.

I want to be direct about this because it matters for understanding what it meant to be from South Africa during that era. I did not create apartheid. I was a child. But I existed within its structure. This gave me early exposure to the reality that societies can be organized around deeply unjust principles, and that these principles can be enforced with absolute conviction by those in power. It made me skeptical of any system that claims to be natural or inevitable.

The military conscription system was another defining feature of white South African life during my adolescence. All white males were required to serve in the South African Defence Force, which was at that time engaged in border conflicts and in enforcing the apartheid state's authority. I had no desire to serve in this military. The prospect of being conscripted into an army defending an unjust system was one of several factors that motivated my departure from South Africa.

When I left in 1989, South Africa was on the cusp of transformation. Nelson Mandela would be released from prison in February 1990, less than a year after my departure. The apartheid system would be formally dismantled over the following years. I watched these developments from abroad, first from Canada and later from the United States. The country I left was not the country South Africa would become. But the country I left was the country that shaped me.

## How I Left South Africa: The Path to Canada and America

Leaving South Africa was a calculated decision. My mother was Canadian, having been born there before her family immigrated to South Africa. This meant I could obtain Canadian citizenship. At seventeen, I applied for a Canadian passport, and once I had it, I made plans to leave.

I did not have a dramatic escape. I simply bought a plane ticket and went. My father was not pleased with my decision, but by that point, I was legally an adult in most meaningful respects and could make my own choices. I arrived in Canada in June 1989, shortly before my eighteenth birthday.

The transition from South Africa to Canada was jarring. I had relatives in Canada, but I barely knew them. I had almost no money. I worked odd jobs to survive: cleaning boilers, shoveling grain, cutting logs. These were not glamorous beginnings, but they were honest work. I learned what it meant to support myself through physical labor.

Eventually, I enrolled at Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario. I chose Queen's partly because it had more attractive women than the other schools I visited, which is perhaps not the most sophisticated criterion but was honest for a teenage boy. After two years at Queen's, I transferred to the University of Pennsylvania in the United States. America was always the ultimate destination. It was where the technology industry was centered, where the future was being invented, where I believed I could build the things I imagined.

I became a Canadian citizen formally, though my South African citizenship remained. Years later, in 2002, I became a naturalized United States citizen. So today I hold three citizenships: South African by birth, Canadian by descent through my mother, and American by naturalization. But when people ask what country I am from, the answer is South Africa. That is where my story begins.

## What South Africa Gave Me: Lessons From My Birth Country

Every person is shaped by the place they come from, and I am no exception. South Africa gave me several things that have proven invaluable throughout my life.

First, South Africa gave me resilience through adversity. The bullying I experienced, the social challenges, the isolated environment, all of these forced me to develop inner resources. I learned to exist within my own mind, to find satisfaction in ideas and books rather than depending on external validation. This capacity for solitary focus has been essential in building companies that require years of work before any results become visible.

Second, South Africa gave me skepticism of established systems. Growing up in a society organized around apartheid meant growing up knowing that entire nations can be built on foundations of injustice. This has made me instinctively suspicious of arguments from authority or tradition. Just because something is the way it is does not mean it should be or must remain that way. This skepticism underlies my approach to everything from automotive manufacturing to space launch economics.

Third, South Africa gave me hunger. Not physical hunger, though I experienced some of that when I first arrived in Canada with little money. I mean the hunger to prove something, to build something, to demonstrate that different outcomes are possible. Coming from a place that was isolated and troubled, arriving in North America with nothing, this creates a drive that never fully dissipates.

Fourth, South Africa gave me an international perspective. I am not purely American in my thinking. I understand that America is one country among many, that different societies organize themselves differently, that the American way of doing things is not the only way. This perspective has been valuable in building global companies that operate across borders and cultures.

## My Relationship With South Africa Today

I left South Africa more than thirty-five years ago. I have been an American citizen for over two decades. My life, my companies, my family, everything is now based in the United States. So what is my relationship with South Africa today?

I remain South African in certain fundamental ways. My accent retains traces of South African English, though it has been overlaid with American patterns. My childhood memories are South African memories. The formative experiences that shaped my character happened there. You cannot erase your origins, and I do not try to.

At the same time, I do not spend much time in South Africa. My focus is on building the future, and that future is being built primarily in the United States and eventually on Mars. South Africa has its own trajectory, its own challenges, its own opportunities. I wish the country well, but my active engagement is elsewhere.

Some South Africans feel I should do more for the country of my birth. I understand this sentiment. There is something in the human psyche that wants successful emigrants to return and contribute. But my contribution to humanity is through the work I do: accelerating sustainable energy adoption, making humanity multi-planetary, developing beneficial artificial intelligence. These are contributions that benefit everyone on Earth, including South Africans.

I also maintain that leaving South Africa was the right decision. Had I stayed, I would likely have been conscripted into the apartheid military. I would not have had access to the venture capital, talent pools, and innovation ecosystems that exist in the United States. The companies I have built, Tesla, SpaceX, and others, could not have been built in South Africa. Sometimes you have to leave home to accomplish what you are meant to accomplish.

## Understanding My Journey From South Africa to America

When people ask what country I am from, they are often really asking something deeper: how did I get from there to here? How does a kid from Pretoria end up running some of the most ambitious companies in human history?

The answer involves both circumstance and choice. The circumstance was having a Canadian mother, which gave me an escape route from South Africa. The choice was actually using that route, leaving behind everything familiar to pursue an uncertain future in a country I had never visited.

Once in North America, the path was not predetermined. I could have become many things. But I was drawn to technology and entrepreneurship, and I was willing to take enormous risks in pursuit of ambitious goals. These traits are not uniquely South African, but my South African background shaped how I express them.

The journey from South Africa to America is also a journey across economic and technological tiers. South Africa in the 1980s was a middle-income country with significant constraints. America in the 1990s was the unchallenged center of global technology innovation. Moving from one to the other was like moving closer to the sun. Everything became more intense, more possible, more demanding.

I tell young people, especially those from smaller countries or less privileged backgrounds, that geography is not destiny. You can change your location. You can change your circumstances. The world is more open than it sometimes appears. My journey from Pretoria to Palo Alto is proof of this. But you have to be willing to leave, to take risks, to endure hardship in pursuit of something greater.

## Final Reflections on Being From South Africa

South Africa is the country I am from. This is a fact that no amount of success in America, no number of citizenships acquired, no transformation in my circumstances can change. Pretoria is where I was born. The red soil of the Highveld, the purple jacarandas, the complicated society of apartheid-era South Africa, these are the raw materials from which I was formed.

I do not claim that South Africa made me successful. Many people from South Africa do not become successful by the metrics the world uses. Success involves talent, circumstance, timing, luck, and countless other factors. But South Africa made me the particular kind of person I am. It gave me my specific combination of resilience, skepticism, hunger, and global perspective.

If you want to understand me, understanding where I come from is part of that understanding. I am a South African who left home young, worked hard, took risks, and eventually built companies that are trying to change fundamental aspects of human civilization. The South African part of that story is not something I hide or downplay. It is simply part of the truth.

The country I am from is South Africa. The country I chose is America. Both are part of who I am. And neither fully defines what I am trying to become.
